pullRequest.body:
Introduce divisors on subsets of nontrivially normed fields. These are standard book-keeping devices used to keep track of pole/vanishing orders of meromorphic objects, such as functions, differential forms or sections in line bundles. Establish that divisors form a lattice-ordered commutative group. The construction that attaches a divisor to a meromorphic or analytic function will come in a follow-up PR.

Divisors are used in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD), which aims to formalize Value Distribution Theory for meromorphic functions on the complex plane. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [cca90b2e40](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22357/commits/cca90b2e403002f1857797d65187b49ca89d7b59)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.Meromorphic.Divisor.Basic` (new file)|1566|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Divisor`
`+ Divisor.counting`
`+ Divisor.logCounting`
`+ DivisorOn`
`+ add_fun`
`+ closedSupport`
`+ closed_compl_of_codiscreteWithin`
`+ codiscreteWithin_iff_locallyEmptyComplementWithin`
`+ codiscreteWithin_iff_locallyFiniteComplementWithin`
`+ deg`
`+ discreteSupport`
`+ discreteTopology_of_codiscreteWithin`
`+ ext`
`+ finiteSupport`
`+ instance (U : Set ùïú) : CoeFun (DivisorOn U) (fun _ ‚Ü¶ ùïú ‚Üí ‚Ñ§)`
`+ instance : Add (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : FunLike (DivisorOn U) ùïú ‚Ñ§`
`+ instance : LE (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : LT (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : Lattice (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : Max (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : Min (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : Neg (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : OrderedAddCommGroup (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : SMul ‚Ñï (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : SMul ‚Ñ§ (DivisorOn U)`
`+ instance : Zero (DivisorOn U)`
`+ le_fun`
`+ lt_fun`
`+ max_fun`
`+ min_fun`
`+ neg_fun`
`+ nhdNE_of_nhdNE_diff_finite`
`+ nsmul_fun`
`+ restrict`
`+ restrict_fun_on_V`
`+ restrict_fun_on_V_compl`
`+ restrict_groupHom`
`+ restrict_groupHom_fun`
`+ restrict_latticeHom`
`+ restrict_latticeHom_fun`
`+ restrict_orderHom`
`+ restrict_orderHom_fun`
`+ support`
`+ supportDiscreteWithin_iff_locallyFiniteWithin`
`+ zero_fun`
`+ zsmul_fun`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Once you've set up the function coercion, `.toFun` should no longer be necessary.
I didn't test, but I guess that
```suggestion
theorem ext {D‚ÇÅ D‚ÇÇ : Divisor U} (h : ‚àÄ a, D‚ÇÅ a = D‚ÇÇ a) : D‚ÇÅ = D‚ÇÇ := DFunLike.ext _ _ h
```
will work.
Implemented as suggested.
I think you get these for free after you set up the `FunLike` instance in the next declaration.

I was able to delete the attribute without consequences. Deleting the instance led to massive errors `typeclass instance is stuck` all over the file.

@jcommelin Please advise.

I would prefer `support D` or `D.support` over `D.toFun.support`.
With `open Function`, I'm optimistic that `support D` will *just work*.
For `D.support`, it would be needed to provide an

```
abbrev support := Function.support D
```
somewhere.
Implemented. I had to modify the abbreviation to `abbrev support (D : Divisor U)  := Function.support D`

```suggestion
  add D‚ÇÅ D‚ÇÇ := by
```
Untested, but I think this works.
If it does, then you now have a `by exact` which you can remove and stay in term mode.

Idem dito for `Neg` and `SMul`.
Implemented.
This lemma should make use of the function coercion that you defined upstairs.

I am not sure I understand. If I delete the `.toFun` then I get a different statement that no longer speaks about functions but about divisors. This renders the simp-lemma moot. I think I need to tell the compiler that I want functions ... either by using `.toFun` or by typecasting (D‚ÇÅ : ùïú ‚Üí ‚Ñ§)`. 

@jcommelin Please advise.
Sorry for being terse, but indeed, please state it using typecasting.

Maybe for the definition of `Divisor` the `ùïú` is a topological space is enough. In this way we can use it in algebraic geometry.

Also, maybe your `Divisor` should be called `DivisorOn`? And `Divisor` just means `DivisorOn univ`.
@acmepjz Thank you for looking at my PR. Let me answer your two proposals separately.
Proposal 2: Implemented as you suggested.

Proposal 1: I am hesitant. Please let me explain why, and what I think could be done instead.

It is correct that the current definition will work with arbitrary topological spaces instead of ùïú. However, divisors are used in complex and algebraic geometry to track the vanishing and pole orders of meromorphic functions defined on vector spaces (and, more generally, complex manifolds or algebraic varieties). This is the first PR in a long series; it does not mention the word "meromorphic" anywhere. The follow-up PRs will definitively use the normed field structure of ùïú.

You have suggested on Zulip that one might introduce a notion of functions with "locally of finite support" as a generalization to `Finsupp`, and then specialize by saying that divisors are functions of locally finite support where the domain is  ùïú and the target is ‚Ñ§. This might be a viable option if the community has sufficient interest in adding this. Do you think we should ask on Zulip people are interested in having functions of locally finite support?

@jcommelin Do you have any opinion here?

But it's harmless in this file only requiring ùïú be a topological space (by this way your definition can also be used, at least for Riemann surfaces); in later applications you can always plug a normed field into it.

I think most definitions in mathlib try to be as general as possible (although not always make sense in mathematics), for example [Algebra.IsSeparable](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Separable.html#Algebra.IsSeparable), it said that

> We define this for general (commutative) rings and only assume F and K are fields if this is needed for a proof.

So I think it's same for your `Divisor`.

It doesn't hurt to weaken the assumption in the definition. That way it could in principle be reused in some other specific cases like Riemann surfaces.
Of course we will need a separate definition for divisors on general varieties/schemes for dimension reasons.

> You have suggested on Zulip that one might introduce a notion of functions with "locally of finite support" as a generalization to Finsupp, and then specialize by saying that divisors are functions of locally finite support where the domain is ùïú and the target is ‚Ñ§. This might be a viable option if the community has sufficient interest in adding this. Do you think we should ask on Zulip people are interested in having functions of locally finite support?

Although this is a viable generalization, I think we should have more use cases beyond just advisors to justify the effort of setting up this definition and the accompanying API.

pullRequest.title: feat: introduce divisors on subsets of nontrivially normed fields
